title: U.S. Stocks Mixed Amid Wave of Bank Earnings Reports; Dow industrials flat, Nasdaq down; Twitter falls after Elon Musk disclosed offer to take the it private
text:
Twitter shares, which earlier were up more than 5%, were recently down 0.9%. Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk—who already holds a more than 9% stake in the social-media company—disclosed an offer to buy the company outright in a deal valuing it at more than $43 billion. Tesla fell 3.5%.

More broadly, the S&P 500's communications services sector, of which Twitter is a component, was down about 1.3%. Its tech sector was off 1.3%.

Big bank shares swung after a batch of earnings reports. Wells Fargo shares fell more than 4% in recent trading after the bank reported a drop in first-quarter earnings. Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Citigroup all reported results that were better than analysts' forecasts.

Big U.S. banks are expected to suffer from comparisons to bumper profits during the pandemic. Analysts expect first-quarter earnings for S&P 500 banks fell 37% from a year ago, according to FactSet.

Looking ahead, corporate results will be scrutinized for guidance on how companies expect to manage tighter policy from the Federal Reserve, with a series of interest-rate increases expected.

"Investors are trying to figure out if the Fed is on the right course. Can they stick the landing in terms of bringing inflation down without bringing the economy down?" said David Donabedian, chief investment officer at CIBC Private Wealth.

The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note rose to 2.804% from 2.688% on Wednesday. While wavering in recent days, the yield on the benchmark note earlier this week hit its highest level since January 2019 as investors gear up for rising interest rates. Bond yields and prices move in opposite directions.

The interest rate on the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage hit 5% for the first time in more than a decade, Freddie Mac said Thursday.

In economic news, U.S. consumer sentiment rose in April, beating the consensus forecast of economists polled by The Wall Street Journal, according to the University of Michigan. And March consumer retail and restaurant spending rose by 0.5% from the previous month, according to the Commerce Department.

In commodity markets, Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, fell 0.8% to $107.92 a barrel. Gold prices declined 0.9%.

Overseas, the Stoxx Europe 600 rose 0.4% as gains for travel stocks balanced losses for telecommunication companies. The European Central Bank said in a statement Thursday that recent economic data made it more likely that the bank would end its net bond purchases in the third quarter, confirming plans to rapidly roll back the easy-money policies adopted during the Covid-19 pandemic.

In Asia, stock markets were mostly higher. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 1.2%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.7% and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.2%.
